awd_titl_txt: Natural Diversity and Mutant Analysis of Regulators of Plant Immunity for Rational Design of Immunity Proteins as Decoys
awd_abstract_narration:
Plant pathogens cause tremendous crop losses worldwide and evolve quickly to overwhelm existing host immunity. Many pathogens deliver effector proteins into their hosts to promote virulence of the pathogen. Over evolutionary time, the plant can evolve to recognize specific effector proteins from the pathogen. The PI's research group has identified a plant protein (a "decoy") that acts as a "mousetrap" for a pathogen effector protein, and enables the plant to mount a strong immune response. This work will determine the genetic parameters necessary for pathogen recognition in the host, in order to help design better decoys and protect crops from infection. This project includes substantial outreach to a local two-year college that serves a diverse student body, including underrepresented groups (37% Hispanic, 24% African American, 19% Asian, 1% Hawaiian) and underprivileged students (68% receive financial aid), in order to expose students to cutting-edge research and broader educational opportunities. 

Dissection of the molecular determinants underlying host immunity will provide a rigorous toolkit to combat the significant problem posed by plant pathogens. HopZ1a, a Pseudomonas syringae type III secreted effector protein, is recognized indirectly through ZAR1, a nucleotide-binding site leucine-rich repeat containing receptor protein, when HopZ1a acetylates the ZED1 pseudokinase. ZED1 appears to be a decoy that has evolved to trap the T3SE into recognition, as it is not a functional kinase and does not have a role in basal immunity. This work will examine ZAR1 and ZED1 natural and mutant diversity in order to develop constraints for rational design of a pathogen decoy. The PI will collaborate with a local two-year college that primarily serves underprivileged students and underrepresented groups, and will host several students each summer to learn new scientific techniques. The lab will design a module on plant immunity that will be taught in the college. This will provide teaching opportunities for students and post-docs, and increase the participation of underrepresented groups in science. Together these efforts will encourage underrepresented students to pursue and excel at multi-disciplinary scientific research, provide outreach opportunities for graduate students and post-docs, and make progress on significant scientific and agricultural problems.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: Plant disease causes substantial crop loss, which is estimated to be $220 Billion worldwide and contributes to insufficient food for the global population. A greater understanding of plant resistance pathways can help design solutions for protecting plants from infection and preventing high levels of crop loss. Pseudomonas syringae is a bacterial pathogen that infects more than 100 plant species by injecting effector proteins in the plant. Effectors have different roles depending on the genetics of the host. Effectors promote growth of the pathogen in a susceptible host but elicit immune responses in resistant plants. The P. syringae effector HopZ1a is recognized by two proteins, the pseudokinase ZED1 and the immune receptor ZAR1, which together trap the pathogen into being recognized by the host plant. In this project, we found that recognition of HopZ1a is conserved across diverse plant species. We identified and characterized protein-protein interactions within ZAR1, that enable sensitive and specific activation of resistance only when a pathogen is present. We discovered natural and induced diversity in ZED1 and ZAR1, which impair recognition of HopZ1a. We found that ZAR1 can interact with many kinases, which enables it to recognize diverse pathogen effector proteins. We found that rationally designed mutations could enhance interactions between kinases and ZAR1. Together, this work will help design engineered immune receptors that can recognize a broad array of pathogens and effector proteins.

 

Broader impacts: In this project, the PI established a collaboration with a 2-year college in the Bay Area that serves a large proportion of underrepresented or under resourced groups. The PI's lab helped teach and run a new 5-week lab module on plant-pathogen interactions. 5 students (2 of whom were members of underrepresented groups) from the college spent the summer in the PI's lab where they built research skills and conceptual thinking, and gained exposure to different careers. Previous students transferred to 4-year colleges, attained employment in the biotechnology sector or are continuing their education. 36 undergraduate students (25 of whom were members of underrepresented groups, and 8 of whom were transfer students from 2-year colleges) were trained in techniques in plant-microbe interactions, plant pathology, molecular biology, genetics, and bioinformatics. 10 of these students were funded for one summer by the PI's NSF REU supplement. Students have moved onto graduate work, professional schools or the workforce. In addition, the PI trained 2 graduate students (1 of whom was a member of an underrepresented group), 2 rotating graduate students (both members of underrepresented groups), and 4 postdocs (2 of whom were members of underrepresented groups). One graduate student finished her dissertation in August 2022. Two postdocs are or will soon be assistant professors. One postdoc is a lab manager, and one postdoc works in patents. This project has enabled training of a highly qualified diverse scientific workforce.


Last Modified: 08/25/2022
Modified by: Jennifer D Lewis
